author: moors
title: DAO Based Travel Documents & IDs
description: Com base em seu local de nascimento, os recém-nascidos são programados para um passaporte poderoso ou sem poder.

f6_assessments.q0: There is not enough information on the feasibility of the proposal and how effectively it addresses the challenge in its entirety.
f6_assessments.q1:
It is very hard to predict the success of a proposal without a way to track progress, and the information and samples provided give little confidence that the proposal will succeed.
It is unclear whether the proposer has done any work of a similar scale previously.
f6_assessments.q2:
We should have an idea as to how the idea's leverage points are superior to those offered by other community members based on the plan. It is important to be aware of why your target customers would benefit from the idea. The reason should be clearly explained in this section of your plan.
It would be helpful to have a better understanding of the proposed metrics and how they could bring value and ROI to the entire Cardano ecosystem. Additionally, the proposer has not provided any references to his past work of similar scope, nor has a detailed project plan been attached to this proposal.
In the absence of a method to track progress, this becomes an extremely vague proposal, where the information and sample documents give little confidence that the proposal is viable.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal seeks to solve the problem of inequality of passports dependent upon country by creating identity documents on Cardano with the Bornstone DAO being the virtual nation state of birth which mostly aligns with the challenge goal of a national id registry.
The proposal could be improved by providing key metrics and goals that more closely align with the challenge, articulating the value to Cardano ecosystem and articulating how the solution scales to address future challenges.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal articulates the feasibility aspects of budget is broken down and reasonable, realistic timetable and plan, resources required and detailed technical explanation of the solution.
The proposal's feasibility could be improved by evidence of experience (linkedin profile), team composition (skills required), additional funding plan (assumes significant token value with limited supporting rationale), and a challenges and risks section (getting nation states to accept Borntstone DAO id as valid for instance).
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal includes a roadmap, milestones, time horizon, metrics/KPIs to measure proposal success, a clear understandable description of the targeted problem and a detailed description of the solution that addresses the problem.
To improve the proposal all of the auditing components are very minimally present and should be expanded upon in detail.

f6_assessments.q0:
This dystopian project does not effectively address the spirit of the Brief in these ways: 

1. It attempts to offer "proof of humanity" under the guise of tokenized travel documentation, without addressing any of the moral implications of putting people on the blockchain as tokens- ie what to do about adoption? right to privacy? point of issuance? what to do with the nullset people? trafficking? fraud? Most importantly, from the Brief's perspective, how exactly will this project enable sustainable prosperity?

2. philosophically, is "proof of humanity" necessary for travel... global commodity trade says no.

3. the project does not effectively address the core intent of the Brief from the inclusion of the DeSoto reference- to strengthen the relatively weak legal structure of property and property rights. 

In the opinion of this assessor, when considered from the Brief's DeSoto perspective, asserting that the path to sustainable prosperity for the developing world is by putting people and their "proof of humanity" on the blockchain is monstrous.
f6_assessments.q1: Given the project's intent to put people's "proof of humanity" on the blockchain and then to only reference technologists on the team, indicates the proposer has not considered significant implications or stakeholder groups, eg there is no plan that includes a governmental perspective on this team, makes the likelihood of success of this project less than highly likely.
f6_assessments.q2: The KPIs and milestones will allow the community to assess progress and judge the probable success of this project.

f6_assessments.q0: I think this idea has a ton of value to be unlocked for nation states. I am not sure if the proposal in its current state is effectively addressing the challenge needs. With no mention of the independent regional differences (e.g. EU has very different travel documents policy than LatAm or the AU) it's hard to assess how proposer plans to practically implement this solution across locales.
f6_assessments.q1: there is little beyond the relevant experience section to audit the team's previous experience building apps. The roadmap and KPI is the 30,000 foot view (we need more detail/specifics). There is also no mention of compliance/regional mandates for digital identifiers which seems like a large oversight in the plan.
f6_assessments.q2: For the requested amount and magnitude of a solution expected to exist with multi-national legal frameworks the proposal does not provide sufficient information in the plan, suggest proposer include more detailed implementation steps, defining risks/tactics and adding depth to the timeline/KPIs as these are needed to audit the progress/success of proposal.

solution: Bornstone DAO pode ser usado para registrar nascimentos na cadeia de bloqueio Cardano, permitindo a produção de passaportes e vistos ilimitados da cadeia de bloqueio.
experience: Adoto uma abordagem centrada no ser humano e baseada no design para ajudar o crescimento de minha comunidade através da criatividade, inovação e design.
